To be admitted to the teacher education program, students must meet specific requirements including a minimum number of credit hours earned, minimum GPA, and passing scores on a basic skills test.
Department: LeBron James Family Foundation College of Education
Description: Special education teachers work with students who have a wide range of learning, mental, emotional and physical disabilities. They adapt general education lessons and teach various subjects, such as reading, writing and math, to students with disabilities. This major leads to a Bachelor of Science degree in Education with a dual licensure in Intervention Specialist (K-12) and Early Childhood Intervention Specialist (Age 3-Grade 3). You will learn to work with diverse learners from Pre-K through high school, and be prepared to take the Ohio Assessments for Educators exams required for licensure. This program is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP). In this program, you will gain the knowledge, skills, and dispositions to work with students who have mild to moderate disabilities in grades K-12, as well as students with a range of disabilities in pre-kindergarten to third grade. You will learn to use assessment data to inform instruction, design and implement individualized education programs, collaborate with families and other professionals, and apply evidence-based practices to support student learning and development. The curriculum emphasizes practical experience through field placements in diverse educational settings.
Accredidation: This program is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Jewelry and Metalsmithing
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Land Surveying
Department: College of Engineering and Polymer Science
Fees: Ohio Resident: $16,096.80/Year; Non-Ohio Resident: $22,396.80/Year (based on 15 credits per semester, including tuition, general fee, and program fee)
Description: The B.S. in Surveying is an ABET-accredited program that prepares graduates to enter the surveying profession at a professional level. Surveyors are involved in a wide range of projects, including measuring and mapping the earth's surface, defining property boundaries, and designing and managing construction projects. The program provides a strong foundation in surveying principles, including geodesy, photogrammetry, remote sensing, and geographic information systems (GIS). Graduates are prepared to work in a variety of settings, including private surveying firms, government agencies, and construction companies. The program also offers opportunities for students to gain hands-on experience through internships and field work. Graduates are eligible to sit for the Fundamentals of Surveying (FS) exam, the first step toward becoming a licensed professional surveyor. This program can be completed in four years on a full-time schedule.
Accredidation: ABET-accredited
CostPerCredit: Ohio Resident: $582.31; Non-Ohio Resident: $844.81 (includes $60.25/credit program fee)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Business Administration in Marketing
Department: College of Business
Description: Marketing is the process of planning and executing the conception, pricing, promotion, and distribution of ideas, goods, and services to create exchanges that satisfy individual and organizational objectives. The Marketing Management program is designed to provide students with a broad and thorough understanding of the theory and practice of marketing. Students learn how to analyze markets and customers, develop new products, price products, communicate the value of products and services, and manage distribution channels. Students are trained in a variety of business environments through the use of marketing simulations, cases, and projects. Upon graduation, students have a strong foundation for successful careers in marketing and sales management.
Accredidation: The College of Business Administration is accredited by AACSB International.

ProgramName: Minor in Marketing
Requirements: This minor is designed for any student desiring a concentration in Marketing. A total of 18 credits are required.
Department: College of Business
Description: A Minor in Marketing requires a minimum of 18 credits. The course requirements provide an overview of marketing principles, consumer behavior, and marketing research. Students will gain an understanding of how businesses identify target markets, develop marketing strategies, and implement promotional activities. This minor enhances a student's major by adding valuable skills applicable across various industries.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies (e.g., Akron Guarantee Scholarship ranges from $1,000 to $7,500 per year)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering
Department: College of Engineering and Polymer Science
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering (BSME) program at The University of Akron is designed to equip students with a robust understanding of how to design, analyze, manufacture, and maintain mechanical systems. Our curriculum blends theoretical knowledge with practical, hands-on experience, preparing graduates to tackle complex engineering challenges across various industries. Students gain expertise in areas such as thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, materials science, dynamics, and control systems. The program emphasizes critical thinking, problem-solving, and innovation, fostering a deep appreciation for the ethical and societal impacts of engineering. Through challenging coursework, state-of-the-art laboratory experiences, and design projects, students develop the skills necessary for successful careers in industry, government, or for further graduate studies.
Accredidation: The Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.

ProgramName: Associate of Applied Science in Mechanical Engineering Technology
Requirements: For direct admission into the associate program in the College of Engineering and Polymer Science, new students must meet the following criteria: Minimum high school GPA of 2.75. Minimum composite ACT score of 18 or minimum composite SAT score of 960 (ERW+M). Note: Students who do not meet these admission criteria will be accepted into the University as an associate studies major in the University College and will be advised by a professional advisor who will assist them in selecting appropriate coursework to prepare them for admission into the a College of Engineering and Polymer Science.
Department: College of Engineering and Polymer Science
Description: Mechanical Engineering Technology students learn to apply engineering principles to the design, development, and improvement of mechanical systems, equipment and processes. Mechanical engineering technology is the largest and most diversified of the engineering technologies and offers a wide range of job opportunities. The Mechanical Engineering Technology (MET) program emphasizes product development, manufacturing processes, quality control, maintenance, design, and analysis. Students learn how to analyze and solve applied engineering problems, especially those involving mechanical components, machinery, and manufacturing systems. Hands-on laboratory work and extensive use of computers prepare graduates for immediate entry into rewarding technical careers. Our graduates are often employed in positions such as product design and testing, manufacturing, quality control, technical sales, industrial operations, and CAD/CAM.
Accredidation: The Associate of Applied Science (AAS) in Mechanical Engineering Technology program is accredited by the Engineering Technology Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering Technology
Requirements: To be admitted to a degree-granting program in the College of Engineering and Polymer Science, you must first be admitted to The University of Akron. Students will be directly admitted to a degree-granting program if they have: Unconditional admission to the University, ACT mathematics sub-score of 22 or higher, OR SAT mathematics sub-score of 550 or higher, and a minimum 2.75 cumulative GPA in high school.
Department: College of Engineering and Polymer Science
Fees: Ohio Resident: $14,594.58/Year; Non-Ohio Resident: $23,765.70/Year (based on 30 credits per year, includes program-specific fees for 2024-25)
Description: Our ABET-accredited Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Mechanical Engineering Technology (MET) program gives students the tools to apply scientific and engineering principles to design, develop, test and manufacture mechanical and thermal devices and systems. Students learn to apply current and emerging technologies with hands-on labs and real-world projects. The curriculum integrates mathematics, science, engineering technology and communication skills. The multidisciplinary program provides a broad understanding of the mechanical, thermal and industrial areas of mechanical engineering technology. Graduates are ready for a variety of careers in fields such as manufacturing, product design, energy, and aerospace.
Accredidation: ABET-accredited
CostPerCredit: $532.43 (Ohio Resident), $947.17 (Non-Ohio Resident), including program-specific fees for 2024-25
CollegeApplicationFee: Ohio Resident: $14,594.58/Year; Non-Ohio Resident: $23,765.70/Year (based on 30 credits per year, includes program-specific fees for 2024-25)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Middle Level Education (Grades 4-9)
Department: School of Education
Description: This program prepares students to teach grades 4-9 in Ohio public schools. Students completing this program will be eligible for an Ohio 4-9 teaching license. Students must select two teaching fields from English Language Arts, Mathematics, Science, and Social Studies. Students who desire a foreign language teaching field should consult a faculty advisor prior to declaring. This program is designed to provide candidates with content knowledge, professional knowledge, and clinical experiences necessary to facilitate optimal learning and development for young adolescents. Candidates develop competencies that demonstrate their knowledge of adolescent development, content standards, instructional strategies, assessment techniques, and collaborative approaches to meet the needs of diverse learners. This program fulfills the requirements for the Ohio Department of Higher Education (ODHE) and the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
Accredidation: This program fulfills the requirements for the Ohio Department of Higher Education (ODHE) and the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Multidisciplinary Studies
Requirements: The program is available to students who have completed at least 30 semester hours of college credit with a cumulative GPA of at least 2.5. Students must meet all general education requirements of the Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences and all university requirements for a baccalaureate degree.
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Multidisciplinary Studies program is a highly customizable degree program designed for students who want to build a unique course of study around their interests and career goals. Students choose three academic disciplines/subject areas (called "focus areas") from across the College of Arts and Sciences. A minimum of 18 credits are required in each of the three chosen focus areas, with a minimum of 9 credits at the 300/400 level in each. Each focus area must be outside the major and minor fields of study. The curriculum requires 36 upper-division credits (300/400 level) for a total of 120 credits. Students work closely with a faculty advisor to craft their program plan.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Music
Requirements:
All prospective undergraduate music majors must audition for admission into the School of Music. The process includes three steps:
1. Apply to The University of Akron. This requires an online application, application fee, and official high school transcript. ACT or SAT scores are optional.
2. Submit the School of Music Application. This application will ask for your musical background.
3. Schedule and complete your audition.
Department: School of Music, Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The B.A. in Music is a more flexible degree program designed for students who wish to combine a strong musical background with a second major or minor in another academic discipline. This degree is typically paired with other disciplines such as business, history, pre-law, pre-med, engineering, or journalism to enable students to pursue a wider array of employment opportunities. This program requires 120 credit hours and culminates in a senior capstone project.
Accredidation: The University of Akron School of Music is an accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Music (NASM).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Nursing
Requirements: Admission to the baccalaureate nursing program is a two-step process: admission to The University of Akron and admission to the School of Nursing. To be directly admitted from high school into the School of Nursing, students need to meet the following criteria: A minimum high school GPA of 3.5; ACT composite score of 24 or SAT composite score of 1160; Completion of required college preparatory high school curriculum as designated by The University of Akron, including: 4 years of English, 4 years of math (including Algebra I, II and geometry), 3 years of science (including biology and chemistry), 3 years of social studies.
Department: School of Nursing
Fees: The total for a full-time Ohio resident is approximately $14,583 per year. This includes the standard tuition and general fee ($12,693/year), the Undergraduate Nursing Program Fee ($900/year), and an estimated $990 for 30 credit hours of nursing-specific course fees ($33/credit).
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) program at The University of Akron is designed to prepare graduates for professional nursing practice across diverse healthcare settings. This comprehensive program emphasizes critical thinking, evidence-based practice, leadership, and ethical decision-making. Students will gain theoretical knowledge and practical skills through a blend of classroom instruction, laboratory simulations, and supervised clinical experiences in various healthcare environments. Our curriculum focuses on health promotion, disease prevention, and the care of individuals, families, and communities throughout the lifespan. Graduates of the BSN program are eligible to take the National Council Licensure Examination (NCLEX-RN) to become a Registered Nurse (RN).
Accredidation: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing at The University of Akron is accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (CCNE), 655 K Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, 202-887-6791.
CostPerCredit: $528.88 per credit hour for Ohio Residents (part-time), plus an additional $33 per credit hour for all NURS designated courses.
CollegeApplicationFee: The total for a full-time Ohio resident is approximately $14,583 per year. This includes the standard tuition and general fee ($12,693/year), the Undergraduate Nursing Program Fee ($900/year), and an estimated $990 for 30 credit hours of nursing-specific course fees ($33/credit).
ScholarshipAmount: $1,000 to $7,500 per year (based on the general Akron Guarantee Scholarship for new students).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Painting and Drawing
Requirements: Admission to the Myers School of Art and all of our programs (BA, BFA) is a two-part process. 1. Apply and be accepted into The University of Akron. 2. Complete a portfolio review with the Myers School of Art. The portfolio should consist of 10-15 pieces of your best and most recent work and include examples of drawing from observation (not from photos).
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts in Painting and Drawing prepares students to be professional artists, to teach art at the collegiate level, and/or to pursue a graduate degree in the field. The program emphasizes both studio practice and art historical knowledge, allowing students to develop a strong artistic voice through a rigorous curriculum. Students explore a variety of traditional and contemporary approaches to painting and drawing, fostering critical thinking, technical proficiency, and creative problem-solving skills.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy
Requirements: To apply for undergraduate admission, you will need: A completed application for admission; Your official high school transcript or GED results; Your ACT or SAT test scores. UA is test-optional for most majors for students entering through fall 2025.
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Concentration: Legal, Justice & Ethics, Logic & Mind, Moral & Political Philosophy, The Human Condition
Description: Philosophy helps us understand ourselves and our place in the world. It provides skills vital to success in virtually any career field, including critical thinking, problem-solving, reading, writing, and logical analysis. Our department offers a Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Philosophy, which provides a comprehensive understanding of historical and contemporary philosophical debates, and a foundation in logic, ethics, and metaphysics. Our graduates go on to successful careers in law, business, education, government, and medicine.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Photography
Requirements:
Admission to any of the undergraduate degree programs in the Myers School of Art is a two-step process:

1. Apply to The University of Akron. This includes a completed online application, a $50 application fee, and an official high school transcript. ACT or SAT scores are optional.

2. Submit a Portfolio. The Myers School of Art requires a portfolio for admission to all of our Bachelor of Fine Arts (B.F.A.) and Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) degree programs.
Department: Myers School of Art
Description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) program with a concentration in Photography provides students with an in-depth understanding of the medium's history, theories, and practices. Students explore a range of photographic techniques, from traditional analog processes to contemporary digital methods, developing a comprehensive skillset for artistic expression and professional application. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, visual literacy, and innovative approaches to image-making, preparing graduates for diverse careers in photography, visual arts, and related fields, or for advanced graduate study.
Accredidation: The School of Art is an accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Art and Design (NASAD).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in PK-12 Multi-age Education
Requirements: The University of Akron has a test-optional admission policy for most majors. You can tell us on the application whether you want us to consider your ACT or SAT test scores. We strongly encourage students with a cumulative high school GPA below a 3.0 to submit a test score and/or a personal statement.
Department: LeBron James Family Foundation School of Education
Description: The PK-12 Multi-age Education program prepares future educators to become highly qualified, licensed teachers in areas such as Visual Art, Music, Physical Education, or Foreign Language. With a focus on inclusive practices, diversity, and technology integration, students will learn how to create engaging and supportive learning environments for all students, including those with exceptionalities.
Accredidation: The University of Akron’s Beeghly College of Education is nationally accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Political Science
Requirements:
Admission to The University of Akron is based on a comprehensive review of a student’s academic profile including cumulative grade-point average and strength of high school curriculum.

A college preparatory curriculum including:
- 4 units of English
- 3 units of math (Algebra I, II, Geometry)
- 3 units of science
- 3 units of social studies
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: Political Science is the study of governments, public policies, political processes, and political behavior within and across countries. Students gain valuable analytical, research, and communication skills necessary for careers in government, law, education, journalism, intelligence, non-profit work, and business. The major includes courses in American government, political theory, public law, international relations, and comparative government. Our faculty members provide students with a solid understanding of current political events while helping students develop the skills to analyze and understand politics more generally.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Polymer Science and Polymer Engineering
Department: College of Engineering and Polymer Science
Fees: $6,108.64/Semester (Ohio Resident) or $10,230.14/Semester (Non-Ohio Resident), plus a $50/credit hour College of Engineering and Polymer Science program fee.
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Polymer Science and Polymer Engineering (PSPE) program at The University of Akron (UA) is a unique and exciting interdisciplinary program, emphasizing the intersection of the traditional fields of chemistry, physics, and engineering. The program is designed to provide students with a fundamental understanding of polymers, their synthesis, characterization, processing, and application. Students will develop skills in polymer design, material selection, manufacturing processes, and product development, preparing them for careers in various industries such as automotive, aerospace, biomedical, consumer products, and advanced materials. The curriculum integrates theoretical knowledge with hands-on laboratory experience, ensuring graduates are well-equipped to address real-world challenges in the polymer industry. Graduates of the PSPE program will be prepared to pursue advanced degrees or enter the workforce directly, contributing to the innovation and advancement of polymer science and engineering.
Accredidation: The Bachelor of Science in Polymer Science and Polymer Engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, www.abet.org.
CostPerCredit: $509.05/credit (Ohio Resident) or $852.51/credit (Non-Ohio Resident), plus a $50/credit hour College of Engineering and Polymer Science program fee.
CollegeApplicationFee: $6,108.64/Semester (Ohio Resident) or $10,230.14/Semester (Non-Ohio Resident), plus a $50/credit hour College of Engineering and Polymer Science program fee.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Primary Inclusive Teacher Preparation (Age 3 thru Grade 5)
Department: School of Education, Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Early Childhood Inclusive Teacher Preparation program prepares individuals to teach young children, including those with and without disabilities, across the birth to age 8 spectrum. This program leads to an Ohio four-year resident educator license for teaching Pre-Kindergarten, Kindergarten, and grades 1-5, and for teaching children with mild-to-moderate disabilities in Pre-Kindergarten, Kindergarten, and grades 1-5.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Printmaking
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences, Myers School of Art
Description: Printmaking is a lively and versatile art form. As a printmaker, you will learn to create images through a variety of processes that transfer images from one surface to another. These processes include etching, lithography, silkscreen, woodcut and digital printmaking. The School of Art is equipped with excellent facilities for these processes. Printmaking majors are encouraged to develop a personal aesthetic in their artwork while learning the craft and techniques necessary to become a skilled printmaker. Additionally, students develop an understanding of historical and contemporary trends in the printmaking field. Graduates from the Printmaking program have a professional foundation for careers as artists, studio assistants, educators and exhibition preparators. Some students choose to continue their studies in graduate school and pursue careers as university professors or museum professionals.

ProgramName: Minor in Professional Selling
Requirements: A cumulative GPA of 2.0 is required for the minor. At least 50% of the course work for the minor must be completed at The University of Akron. No more than one D is permitted in the minor.
Department: College of Business
Description: The Minor in Professional Selling offers an opportunity for students to complement their major with the important functional area of professional selling. This minor prepares students for entry-level sales positions, as well as provides them with skills necessary to be successful in many different fields.
Accredidation: AACSB International accreditation for the College of Business Administration.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, financial need, major, and/or other criteria

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Psychology
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) in Psychology at The University of Akron provides a robust education in the scientific study of human behavior and mental processes. This program offers a strong foundation for students pursuing careers in human services, education, business, or those planning to continue their education in graduate programs such as counseling, social work, law, and medicine. Students explore diverse areas including cognitive psychology, developmental psychology, social psychology, abnormal psychology, and research methods. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, research skills, and ethical considerations in psychological practice, preparing graduates to understand and address complex human issues effectively.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Respiratory Therapy
Requirements:
Admission to the Respiratory Therapy Program's professional sequence is competitive and is not guaranteed by admission to The University of Akron. Students must meet the following minimum requirements to be considered for admission:

- Minimum 2.75 overall GPA.
- Completion of all prerequisite courses with a grade of 'C' or better (a 'C-' is not acceptable).
- Completion of a program application by the established deadline.
- Completion of a program specific interview.
- Submission of two letters of reference.
- Completion of 8 hours of clinical observation with a Registered Respiratory Therapist (RRT).
- Successful completion of a background check, health records, immunizations, drug screen and physical exam.
Department: School of Allied Health
Description: Respiratory therapists provide care for patients with heart and lung diseases, including premature infants, children, and adults. They are part of the health care team and provide life support and ventilator management in critical care settings, including emergency rooms and intensive care units. This program, offered by the School of Allied Health Sciences, combines the advantages of a full-service university with the extensive clinical resources of Akron-area health care facilities. Upon graduation, you are eligible to sit for the National Board for Respiratory Care (NBRC) Therapist Multiple-Choice and Clinical Simulation examinations. As a student in the Bachelor of Science in Respiratory Therapy program, you will develop the specialized skills needed to assess, treat, and manage patients with cardiopulmonary problems. You will learn to perform various diagnostic tests and therapeutic procedures, including mechanical ventilation, oxygen therapy, aerosol treatments, and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). The program also emphasizes critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication skills essential for effective patient care and collaboration within a healthcare team.
Accredidation: The Bachelor of Science in Respiratory Therapy program at The University of Akron is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation for Respiratory Care (COARC).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Business Administration in Risk Management and Insurance
Requirements: To be directly admitted into a bachelor's degree program in the College of Business, you must meet ONE of the following criteria: Cumulative high school GPA of 3.0 or higher; OR ACT composite score of 21 or higher; OR SAT combined score of 1060 or higher (for tests after March 2016).
Department: College of Business
Description: The BBA in Risk Management and Insurance at The University of Akron is a well-established and highly respected program, known for its strong industry connections and successful alumni. Risk management and insurance professionals analyze and manage various risks facing businesses and individuals, including financial, operational, strategic, and hazard risks. They design and implement strategies to mitigate these risks, protect assets, and ensure financial stability. This program prepares students for various careers in the risk management and insurance industry. You will develop a strong foundation in business principles and specialized knowledge in risk assessment, insurance policies, claims management, and financial planning. Our curriculum is designed to be comprehensive and practical, preparing you for immediate entry into the industry.
Accredidation: The College of Business is accredited by AACSB International.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Business Administration in Sales Management
Department: College of Business
Description: The Bachelor of Business Administration, Sales Management program focuses on the sales function of an organization. This degree will prepare students to be successful as professional salespeople and sales managers in today’s dynamic business environment. Students learn how to identify customer needs, present solutions, manage accounts, and develop strong relationships. Graduates will have the knowledge and skills necessary to be successful in a variety of sales and sales management positions in business-to-business and business-to-consumer settings across various industries. Students gain an understanding of sales strategies, sales operations, and sales leadership. An emphasis is placed on developing professional selling skills, ethical decision making, and the use of technology in sales. In addition, students complete an internship to gain real-world experience.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Sculpture
Requirements: Admission to the Myers School of Art is a two-step process: 1. Apply to The University of Akron 2. Submit a Portfolio. All first-year and transfer students who want to become a major in the Myers School of Art must be accepted to The University of Akron AND submit a portfolio for acceptance to the school. There is NO statement of intent, artist statement, or letter of recommendation required for the portfolio submission.
Department: Myers School of Art

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Social Work
Requirements:
To be admitted into the professional social work sequence, students must meet the following requirements:
- Completion of at least 45 semester credits.
- An overall GPA of 2.50 or higher.
- Completion of the prerequisite courses with a grade of C- or better.
- Completion of the professional sequence application, including an essay. Applicants are asked to respond to a prompt about a social problem of interest to them and why they believe social work is the appropriate profession to address this problem.
Department: College of Health and Human Sciences
Description: At The University of Akron, the Bachelor of Arts in Social Work (BASW) program prepares students for beginning professional social work practice in a variety of settings. Students will acquire the generalist knowledge, skills, and values to work with individuals, families, groups, organizations, and communities. The curriculum emphasizes social justice, diversity, and evidence-based practice within a strengths-based, ecological framework. Graduates are prepared for direct service roles, advocacy, community engagement, and further education in social work.
Accredidation: The BASW program is fully accredited by the Council on Social Work Education (CSWE).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Chemistry with a Polymer Option
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The B.S. in Chemistry with Polymer Option is designed to provide students with a solid foundation in the core chemistry disciplines in addition to a substantial background in polymer science. The curriculum includes course work in organic chemistry, inorganic chemistry, analytical chemistry, physical chemistry, biochemistry and polymer chemistry. Students are required to complete a minimum of 13 credit hours of polymer-related courses. Students are also required to complete a 3-credit hour research experience or co-op experience. All students in this program are encouraged to engage in undergraduate research with a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry or the School of Polymer Science and Polymer Engineering. The Polymer Option is an excellent choice for students interested in graduate studies in polymer science and engineering or for students interested in working in the polymer industry.
Accredidation: Approved by the American Chemical Society (ACS).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Mild/Moderate Intervention Specialist (Grades K - 12)
Department: LeBron James Family Foundation School of Education

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Moderate/Intensive Intervention Specialist (Grades K - 12)
Requirements: To apply for general undergraduate admission, students need a completed application and an official high school transcript. The University of Akron is test-optional for the 2024-25 academic year, so students are not required to submit an ACT or SAT score for admission consideration. To be fully admitted into the School of Education for this program, students must have a minimum 2.5 overall GPA.
Department: LeBron James Family Foundation School of Education
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Intervention Specialist (K-12) prepares students to teach individuals with moderate/intensive needs in grades K-12. The program also leads to eligibility for the Ohio moderate/intensive intervention specialist teaching license. The program integrates general education and specialized instruction in pedagogy, curriculum, assessment, technology, classroom management, and professional collaboration to maximize learning for students with disabilities. This program prepares candidates to work with students who have moderate to intensive learning and/or behavioral disabilities. Throughout the program, you will learn to implement evidence-based practices for academic, social-emotional, and behavioral instruction, manage a classroom with diverse learners, and collaborate with families and other professionals. In addition to a comprehensive curriculum, the program offers extensive fieldwork experiences, including diverse classroom settings and a full-time student teaching experience.
Accredidation: The baccalaureate degree program in education at The University of Akron is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP). The University of Akron’s professional education programs are approved by the Ohio Department of Higher Education (ODHE).
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $5,500 per year (Akron Guarantee Scholarship)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Early Childhood Intervention Specialist (Age 3 - Grade 3)
Requirements: Admission to The University of Akron is based on a comprehensive review of a student's overall high school record including cumulative grade-point average and strength of curriculum. Test scores (ACT or SAT) are optional for most applicants for admission.
Department: LeBron James Family Foundation College of Education
Description: The Early Childhood Intervention Specialist program leads to a Bachelor of Science degree in Education and an Ohio teaching license for Early Childhood Intervention Specialist (Age 3 – Grade 3). It prepares teachers of young children with disabilities in a variety of educational settings. The program provides a foundation in theories of child development and learning, curriculum methods, assessment, teaching strategies, working with families and other professionals, and legal issues. Students complete extensive field experience, including student teaching, in diverse settings.
Accredidation: Approved by the Ohio Department of Higher Education (ODHE) and accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in History/Law 3+3
Department: Buchtel College of Arts & Sciences
Description: The University of Akron's Bachelor of Arts in History/Juris Doctor 3+3 program allows high-achieving undergraduate students to earn both their bachelor's and law degrees in just six years, rather than the traditional seven. This program is an excellent opportunity for students who are committed to pursuing a career in law. You will gain a strong foundation in history, critical thinking, research, and writing skills, all of which are essential for success in law school and beyond. The 3+3 program not only saves you a year of tuition and living expenses but also accelerates your entry into the legal profession. Upon completion of the three-year undergraduate portion of the program, you will matriculate to the School of Law, where your first year of law school credits will count towards both your bachelor's degree and your Juris Doctor.
Accredidation: The University of Akron and all of its programs are accredited by the Higher Learning Commission.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy/Law 3+3
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The Philosophy/Law 3+3 program allows high-achieving undergraduate students to earn a Bachelor of Arts degree in Philosophy and a Juris Doctor (JD) degree in six years. Students complete their undergraduate studies in three years (90 credits) and then matriculate to the School of Law. Upon successful completion of their first year in the School of Law (30 credits), the JD credits are applied toward the Bachelor of Arts degree in Philosophy. Students then complete their remaining two years of law school to earn the Juris Doctor degree. This accelerates the process of earning both degrees by one year, saving time and tuition expenses.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based (Jarvie Heisey, Bahlmann, and Portz scholarships)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Political Science/National Security
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Political Science/National Security is a multidisciplinary program offered by the Department of Political Science. It addresses the growing need for a national security workforce capable of addressing the complex challenges facing the United States in the 21st century. The program is designed to provide students with a strong foundation in political science, international relations, and security studies, preparing them for careers in government, intelligence, defense, and international organizations. Students will develop critical thinking, analytical, and communication skills essential for understanding and responding to national security threats and challenges.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Political Science/Law 3+3
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: Earn your bachelor's degree in political science and your Juris Doctor (J.D.) in only six years instead of seven with this joint accelerated program. As a part of this program, you will gain hands-on experience through internships and mock trials to give you a strong foundation for your future career. You will learn skills in critical thinking, writing, and analysis to help you become a successful attorney. We also offer a 4+3 program that allows you to earn both degrees in seven years, where you will complete your undergraduate degree in four years and your J.D. in three.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy, Political Science, and Economics
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy, Political Science, and Economics (PPE) provides students with a multidisciplinary understanding of these three intertwined fields. This degree is designed to give students a comprehensive liberal arts education that focuses on critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and analytical skills. The program prepares students for a wide range of careers in law, public service, business, and non-profit organizations, as well as for advanced studies in law, public policy, or academic fields. The PPE program offers: A broad foundation in philosophical thought, political systems, and economic principles. The ability to analyze complex social, political, and economic issues from multiple perspectives. Strong skills in critical thinking, problem-solving, and ethical decision-making. Preparation for leadership roles in various sectors. Opportunities for internships, research, and study abroad experiences.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy, Sociology and Psychology
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description:
The B.A. in Philosophy, Sociology and Psychology is a uniquely interdisciplinary program focused on the study of human beings and the ways in which individuals and groups interact in a diverse and complex world. This program provides students with a broad and rigorous exposure to the foundational theories and methods within the fields of Philosophy, Sociology, and Psychology, helping them to develop critical thinking, communication, and research skills applicable to a wide variety of careers and post-graduate study.
Students in the program examine topics such as:
*   Ethics, values, and morality
*   Social justice and inequality
*   Human behavior and cognition
*   Cultural diversity
*   Critical reasoning and argumentation
The interdisciplinary nature of the program encourages students to analyze complex problems from multiple perspectives, fostering a holistic understanding of societal challenges and human experience. Graduates are prepared for careers in fields such as social work, counseling, education, public policy, human resources, law, and research, or for advanced studies in any of the three disciplines or related interdisciplinary fields.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Sociology
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) degree in sociology provides you with the intellectual tools to understand the social world. Sociology is the scientific study of human society and social behavior. Sociologists examine the organization of social groups, institutions, and societies; patterns of social inequality; the causes and consequences of social change; and the relationships between individuals and society. The sociology major at UA emphasizes critical thinking, scientific inquiry, and social justice. Sociology majors learn to think critically about society, conduct research, and analyze data using both qualitative and quantitative methods. A B.A. in sociology also provides an excellent liberal arts background for students planning on pursuing graduate or professional training in law, social work, business, public administration, or other fields.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Spanish
Requirements: To be considered for admission, applicants must submit the online application, a $50 application fee, and an official high school transcript. The University of Akron has a test-optional admission policy for most majors. Applicants can indicate on their application whether they want their ACT or SAT scores to be used in the review process.
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description:
PROGRAM GOALS: Provide students with a solid foundation in the Spanish language. Familiarize students with the cultural, social, and political contexts of Spanish-speaking peoples. Help students develop an understanding of literary traditions and critical approaches to Hispanic literatures. Foster students' critical thinking, analytical, and communication skills. Prepare students for careers in diverse fields that require proficiency in Spanish and cultural competence. Cultivate in students an appreciation for global citizenship and intercultural understanding.

STUDENT LEARNING OUTCOMES: Students will demonstrate advanced proficiency in oral and written communication in Spanish. Students will analyze and interpret literary and cultural texts in Spanish. Students will evaluate the social, political, and historical contexts of Spanish-speaking communities. Students will apply critical thinking skills to current events and global issues concerning the Hispanic world. Students will articulate the relevance of Spanish language and culture in a globalized world.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Corrosion Engineering
Requirements: The College has a direct admission policy. Students who meet The University of Akron admission requirements and indicate an interest in a major in the College of Engineering and Polymer Science on their application for admission will be admitted directly to that major. To be admitted to the University, students must have graduated from an accredited high school (or have a GED) and have a cumulative high school GPA of at least 3.0. In addition, students should have the following high school coursework: English (4 units); Math (4 units, including Algebra I, Algebra II, Geometry, and a higher-level math); Science (3 units, including Chemistry); Social Studies (3 units).
Department: College of Engineering and Polymer Science
Description:
Corrosion is the destructive attack of a metal by reaction with its environment. It affects almost every industry, causing significant economic losses, safety issues and environmental damage. Corrosion engineers are critical in understanding, preventing and controlling corrosion to extend the life of materials, ensuring safety and minimizing costs in many fields including infrastructure, biomedical, aerospace, oil and gas, manufacturing, and defense.

The University of Akron’s Bachelor of Science in Corrosion Engineering program is the first and only one of its kind in the United States. Our graduates are highly sought after by industry, government and graduate schools. Students in the program develop a strong background in materials science, electrochemistry and corrosion control engineering principles. The program emphasizes hands-on experience, with students participating in co-op work experiences, undergraduate research, and laboratory-intensive courses.

Our graduates are prepared to address real-world corrosion challenges by applying engineering principles to design, evaluate and implement corrosion prevention and control strategies. They gain expertise in:

*   Understanding the fundamentals of corrosion mechanisms and material degradation processes.
*   Designing and implementing corrosion control strategies, including material selection, protective coatings, cathodic protection, and inhibitors.
*   Utilizing advanced analytical techniques to diagnose corrosion problems and assess material performance.
*   Applying economic and environmental considerations in corrosion engineering solutions.
*   Collaborating effectively in multidisciplinary teams to solve complex engineering challenges.

ProgramName: Minor in Business Data Analytics
Department: College of Business
Description: The minor in Business Data Analytics (BDA) prepares students with fundamental knowledge and skills in data analytics that are applicable to most fields of business and management. By working with real-world data, students develop valuable skills in collecting, processing, analyzing and interpreting large data sets with the goal of making better, more informed business decisions. Skills include data visualization, statistical analysis, database management, and more.

ProgramName: Minor in Economics
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The minor in economics is designed for students of any major who want to develop a deeper understanding of current economic issues without committing to a full major. Understanding economics helps students make better decisions in their personal, professional, and civic lives. It provides a solid analytical framework for a wide array of career options, including law, business, journalism, public policy, healthcare, and foreign service. It also provides excellent preparation for graduate study in business, law, and other fields.

ProgramName: Minor in Leadership and Human Resources
Department: College of Business
Description: The Leadership and Human Resources minor is designed to help students acquire a foundation of knowledge and skills in organizational behavior and human resource management (HRM). Students will learn about topics such as motivation, teamwork, leadership, training and development, performance management, and compensation. This minor is an excellent complement to many majors across campus.

ProgramName: Minor in Information Systems Management
Department: College of Business Administration
Accredidation: Accredited by AACSB International – The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB).

ProgramName: Minor in Risk Management and Insurance
Department: College of Business
Description: Risk is a part of our personal and professional lives. Risk management and insurance professionals analyze, measure and treat risks. Their job is to protect people and organizations from financial losses stemming from property, casualty, liability, and other risks. They protect assets such as homes, cars, businesses and even lives. The risk management and insurance minor prepares students to analyze and evaluate risk, assess risk financing options, and implement risk solutions. Graduates are prepared for careers in risk management and insurance. Students are prepared to take the AIDA and AINS exams.
Accredidation: The College of Business at The University of Akron is accredited by AACSB International, the premier accrediting agency for business schools worldwide.

ProgramName: Minor in Supply Chain/Operations Management
Requirements: A student must have a minimum cumulative grade-point average of 2.0 to be awarded a minor. A minimum of 9 credits for any minor must be successfully completed at The University of Akron.
Department: College of Business
Description:
Enhance your business education by adding a minor in Supply Chain/Operations Management. This minor will give you a fundamental understanding of critical business functions such as purchasing, logistics, inventory management and operations planning. Graduates with this minor will acquire the skills needed to manage the flow of goods and services from suppliers to customers.
What You'll Learn
* Recognize and apply best practices in purchasing, logistics, inventory management, production and process improvement.
* Understand the strategic importance of operations and supply chain management within an organization.
* Develop analytical and problem-solving skills for effective decision-making in operations and supply chain management environments.
Accredidation: AACSB International – the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB) accreditation for the College of Business Administration.
CostPerCredit: $559.78 (Ohio Resident) / $845.59 (Non-Ohio Resident) per credit hour, plus a $26.15 per credit hour College of Business fee.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Applied AI & Information Systems
Requirements: To apply, please submit the following: Application for admission; $50 application fee; Official high school transcript or GED scores; ACT or SAT scores (optional). The minimum cumulative high school GPA for regular admission is a 2.3 on a 4.0 scale.
Department: College of Business

ProgramName: Associate of Arts in Communication Option
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: Students pursuing the Associate of Arts in Communication Option are exposed to a broad knowledge of communication theory and practice. The program helps students develop a foundational knowledge of communication, strengthen analytical and critical thinking, and foster an appreciation for diverse cultures and backgrounds. The curriculum prepares students for entry-level positions in communication-related fields or transfer to a bachelor's degree program.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Humanities Divisional
Requirements: To apply for admission, you will need to complete the online application, pay the non-refundable application fee, and submit your official high school transcript. The University of Akron has a test-optional admission policy. You may submit your ACT or SAT scores if you have them, but scores are not required for admission for most programs.
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The Humanities Divisional Major is for students who want to develop their own interdisciplinary major in the Humanities, focusing on topics, periods, or areas of interest that do not fit into traditional departmental majors. To declare the Humanities Divisional major, students must consult with the chair of the Department of Philosophy to design a proposal for their program. The Divisional Major in Humanities consists of 30 credits above the 100-level approved by the chair of the Department of Philosophy, with no more than 15 credits from any one department. For additional information, contact the Department of Philosophy at 330-972-7078.

ProgramName: Associate of Science in Construction Management Option
Requirements: Admission to the Associate of Science in Construction Management Option is the same as admission to the University. To apply, the university requires a completed online application and an official high school transcript (or GED certificate). The submission of ACT/SAT scores, letters of recommendation, and a personal statement/essay are optional.
Department: College of Engineering and Polymer Science
Description: The Associate of Science in Construction Management (ASCM) provides students with the foundational knowledge and skills required for careers in the construction industry. This program focuses on project management, construction methods, cost estimating, safety, and sustainable building practices. Graduates are prepared for entry-level positions in residential, commercial, and industrial construction, or for seamless transfer into a related bachelor's degree program. The University of Akron's ASCM program stands out due to its hands-on learning approach, experienced faculty, and strong industry connections. Students benefit from practical training through labs, site visits, and internship opportunities, ensuring they gain real-world experience. Our curriculum is regularly updated to reflect current industry trends and technologies, providing graduates with a competitive edge.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences, Divisional PPE Track
Requirements: To apply for undergraduate admission, applicants must submit a completed online application, official high school transcript(s) or GED certificate, and a $50 nonrefundable application fee. The University of Akron has a test-optional admission policy for most majors, meaning applicants have the choice to submit ACT or SAT test scores as part of their application.
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences with a Divisional PPE Track (Philosophy, Politics, and Economics) is an interdisciplinary program focusing on the intersection of these three critical areas. This track provides students with a robust understanding of social, political, and economic systems, emphasizing critical thinking, analytical reasoning, and ethical decision-making. Students explore fundamental questions related to justice, governance, markets, and human behavior through a comprehensive curriculum that integrates perspectives from philosophy, political science, and economics. This rigorous program prepares graduates for diverse careers in public service, law, business, non-profit organizations, and advanced academic pursuits by developing strong communication skills, problem-solving abilities, and a global perspective.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences, Divisional PSP Track
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: This interdisciplinary major is designed for students with strong academic records who are interested in pursuing graduate or professional education. The Divisional PSP (Pre-Service Preparation) Track is a challenging major tailored for students who intend to enter a professional Master’s program (such as law, social work, public administration, public policy, or business) or a doctoral program (such as in economics, political science, sociology, psychology, or history). The Divisional PSP Track is housed within the Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences in Interdisciplinary Programs. Its students receive intensive advising, take courses that encourage critical thinking, quantitative literacy, and analytical abilities, complete a capstone seminar, and participate in an internship or research experience.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences, Divisional
Department: Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences with a divisional major is designed for students interested in a broad-based education covering multiple areas within the social sciences, rather than focusing on a single discipline. This program offers a flexible curriculum that allows students to explore various fields such as anthropology, economics, political science, sociology, and psychology. Students gain a comprehensive understanding of human behavior, societal structures, and cultural dynamics, preparing them for a wide range of careers or further graduate studies. This program stands out for its interdisciplinary approach, fostering critical thinking, analytical skills, and a global perspective. Students benefit from the expertise of faculty across multiple departments, engaging in diverse topics and research methodologies. The flexibility of the divisional major allows students to tailor their coursework to their interests, creating a personalized academic journey. Graduates are well-equipped for roles in government, non-profit organizations, research, education, and various private sector industries requiring strong analytical and communication skills.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Nursing (Accelerated)
Requirements:
The admission requirements for The University of Akron Accelerated BSN Program Option are:

- Baccalaureate degree from a regionally accredited college/university with an overall GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
- A GPA of 3.0 or higher in all prerequisite courses (no grade lower than a “C” accepted).
- Completion of all of the prerequisite courses prior to beginning the accelerated nursing program.
- Two recommendation forms.
- TEAS test minimum total score of 70%. The TEAS test may be taken a maximum of two times in a calendar year with at least 30 days between attempts. The higher of the two scores will be used.
- Written essay.
- A personal interview with School of Nursing faculty may be required.
- A completed application to The University of Akron as a transfer student.
- A completed application to The University of Akron School of Nursing.
Department: School of Nursing
Description: This accelerated baccalaureate degree program is designed for individuals who hold a bachelor's degree in another field and want to become a registered nurse. This fast-paced program provides students with the opportunity to complete the BSN in 12 months in a full-time, rigorous, face-to-face format. Students are admitted once a year in May and follow a prescribed course of study designed to lead to successful completion of the NCLEX-RN and entry into professional nursing practice. Graduates are prepared for leadership roles, graduate study, and a variety of practice settings within the healthcare system.
Accredidation: The School of Nursing offers degree programs accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (CCNE).
CostPerCredit: Ohio Resident: $565.25 per credit hour; Non-Ohio Resident: $905.45 per credit hour
ScholarshipType: University scholarships, Departmental scholarships, Private scholarships

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Nursing (for LPNs)
Requirements: Admission to the LPN to BSN program option is competitive. To be considered for admission, applicants must have a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher. In addition, students must have completed and passed both anatomy and physiology courses (with labs), chemistry, and English with a 'C' or better. Applicants must also hold an active LPN license in the state in which they will be completing their clinicals.
Department: School of Nursing

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Nursing (RN to BSN)
Department: School of Nursing
Description: The online RN to BSN program at The University of Akron is designed for registered nurses who have an associate degree in nursing or a hospital diploma and want to earn their Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) degree. The program provides the knowledge and skills necessary for the professional nurse to meet the health care needs of diverse populations. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, leadership, evidence-based practice, and community health. The RN to BSN program is taught by experienced faculty who are dedicated to helping students succeed. The program is flexible and can be completed at a pace that fits your busy schedule. Courses are offered online, allowing you to learn from anywhere, anytime.
Accredidation: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing at The University of Akron is accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (http://www.ccneaccreditation.org).
